hi,

but what's about testing setter-methodes, if in there you're
doing som=
e value (-range) checks ?! i think then it make
sense to test them ..

gabi=




-----Urspr=FCngliche Nachricht-----
Von: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbr@=
diasparsoftware.com]
Gesendet: Donnerstag, 2. Mai 2002 20:41
An: junit@yaho=
ogroups.com
Betreff: RE: [junit] Testing getXXX( ) and setXXX( ) methods


=
Quoting "Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC)" <timothy.j.stevens@...>:=


> 
> 	Can't break!!?? You never make typos and return the wrong variable
=
> in a getter, or set the wrong variable in a setter? If so, you're a
> bet=
ter
> coder than me :)

I hope this was tongue-in-cheek. I don't think I ha=
ve *ever* returned the
wrong 
variable from a getX() method[1]. In order to=
 make this mistake, I'd have to
be 
drunk. As for setting the wrong variabl=
e in a setX() method, see my previous

message. I've made that mistake exac=
tly once.

Folks, don't test the getX() and setX() methods; but rather test=
 that the constructor stores the appropriate parameter in the appropriate f=
ield. I
know 
I'm about 100 times more likely to write a bug there than in =
the getX() or
setX
() method itself.

J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
President, Di=
aspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Let's write software=
 that people understand.

[1] Note that I'm ignoring cases where the compil=
er caught a typo.
